title: Who would you nominate as the greatest of all novelists? - Quora

response.answer_text: I know this more or less avoids the question, but honestly, I wouldn’t nominate any single writer. The history of the novel is too diverse to make fair comparisons. In the 18th Century, for example, the novel was considered a sub-literate form. Nonfiction was all the rage. Hence the reason you get guys like Defoe, Swift and Fielding writing tons of nonfiction pamphlets and occasionally a novel. If you wrote fiction back then, you probably wrote plays. The novel was in its infancy. The 19th Century, by contrast, saw the rise of the novel as the premiere form of entertainment. You get Dickens, Trollope, Hugo, Tolstoy, etc. This era probably produced the greatest novelists, simply because the novel grew to encompass such a huge range of elements. Think of Les Miserables, Hugo’s masterpiece: you get a detective story, history lessons, military lectures, a diatribe on the construction of Parisian sewers…you could stuff so much in a novel back then. The 20th Century cleaned out a lot of those elements, thanks mostly to competition with other forms of entertainment, as well as the rise of other technologies. You don’t need to describe houses and landscapes and clothing, etc. in great detail when you live in an era that has mass photography. These days, you can never leave home but know exactly what London looks like, or Paris, or wherever. You could compare novelists from different eras, though, based upon how well their work has sunk into the cultural conscience. For example, everyone is familiar with Frankenstein, by Mary Shelley, even if they’ve never read the novel or seen any of the movies. The story, its themes and characters, have become part of the culture. Personally, I think this is how novelists last. By that standard, Mary Shelley, Arthur Conan Doyle and Bram Stoker are greater novelists than, say, Virginia Wolfe or William Faulkner. Clearly, this discounts anything related to style, sentence structure, etc. I don’t know that it’s a fair way to compare writers, although I would argue that it’s how every writer is eventually judged. Either your work becomes part of the culture, or you are forgotten.

Fyodor Dostoevsky (Greatest of all time) My favorite author. His writings are a treat to readers. No other author can portray human emotions as exquisitely as Dostoevsky. His characters are generally dark, irritable, solitary, restless and live gloomy lives. FD, with his wonderful articulation of their mental states and emotions makes the characters alive. He is champion of psychological fiction. Best works- Crime and Punishment, The Brothers Karamazov, Demons, Notes from underground, The Idiot. Other greats are: Leo Tolstoy- Tolstoy used a moralistic tone. His characters evolve through the story and the mastery with which he makes you believe in their evolution is fantastic. Best works- Anna Karenina, War and Peace, Resurrection. Jane Austen - Jane Austen enjoys a towering status as one of greatest writers of all time. Matriarch of classic literature, her works are read across the world and considered as finest literature. Best works- Her USP is that unlike other authors, she does not have one or two great and rest average works. All her books are said to be Great. I have only read Pride and Prejudice and Emma. Charles Dickens- Immensely popular writer of Victorian Era, whose popularity I doubt has ever seen a dip. His comic sense was spot on. His stories are a great depiction of Victorian society. He would hit at the social evils and limitations of humanity with a fine, charismatic ease. Best works- A Christmas Carol, Great Expectations, Oliver Twist. Ernest Hemingway- His stories are set in the backdrop of wars. His writing style is delicate and soothing. An american great and Nobel prize winner. Hemingway has written a great volume of books Best works- For whom the Bell tolls, The Old Man and the Sea, The Sun also rises.
